title: #InTheirWords
credits_intro:
This is a pivotal moment in history for the gay community and America. The Supreme Court will hear oral arguments in April about whether state bans on same-sex marriage are constitutional. If the court decides in June that the bans are unconstitutional, couples across the country will be granted federal marriage rights. If not, the issue will remain at the state level.

USA TODAY took this opportunity to hear from people within the gay community #InTheirWords about how this decision will impact their lives and why they want marriage rights.

people.person_intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
people.person_name: Rev. Holly Clark-Porter and Rev. Kaci Clark-Porter
people.person_bio: Rev. Kaci Clark-Porter and Rev. Holly Clark-Porter were jointly ordained at Delaware’s First and Central Presbyterian Church, where Kaci is an associate pastor. Holly is a minister at Big Gay Church, a community for LGBT Christians that meets once a month. They are from Texas and both women had prior marriages to men.

people.person_intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
people.person_bio: Gregory Angelo is the executive director of Log Cabin Republicans, an organization dedicated to furthering the political interests of the LGBT community. Angelo also serves as executive director of the Liberty Education Forum, a non-partisan think tank that advocates acceptance of the LGBT community. He lives in Washington, D.C.

people.person_intro: Meet Austin and Aaron. The twins are YouTube stars.
people.person_bio: Austin and Aaron Rhodes are twin brothers and models living in Los Angeles. The YouTube personalities came out to their father in a YouTube post video that went viral.

people.person_intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights activist with the Latino GLBT History Project.
people.person_bio: Lena Hernandez is a consultant in Washington, D.C. She previously worked as the special assistant to the president & CEO of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute. Hernandez was awarded the Latina Leadership Award by the Latino GLBT History Project for her advocacy work. She is expecting her first child with her wife, Candy, in August. The couple married in Virginia.

people.person_intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
people.person_bio: Kaleb Anthony and Kordale Lewis are fathers raising three children together. The pair became Internet celebrities after a photo of them helping their daughters get ready for school went viral on Instagram. Their family was featured in a Nikon commercial for the company’s “I am generation image” campaign. Kordale published a book about their life together in 2014 called Picture Perfect. They live in Georgia and want to get married as soon as it's recognized in their state.

people.person_intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
people.person_bio: Mala Kumar is an Indian-American novelist with a background in international development. She quit her job at the United Nations because she did not feel the organization supported their LGBT employees. She wrote a column about her decision and published it on The Advocate website in 2014. She came out publicly in the piece with the closing line "I am gay." Her recently published novel, The Paths of Marriage, chronicles tension between a lesbian and her Indian-American family.

people.person_intro: Meet Allen. He's a practicing Catholic who is also gay.
people.person_bio: Allen Rose serves on the board of DignityUSA, a national organization founded in 1969 that champions LGBT Catholics. Rose advocates for the Catholic Church to accept the LGBT community and same-sex marriage legislation. He's engaged to be married this year in Washington, D.C.

people.person_intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
people.person_bio: Julie and Hillary Goodridge were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case Goodridge v. Department of Public Health. Massachusetts became the first state to legalize same-sex marriage when the state's Supreme Judicial Court ruled in their favor. The two married on May 17, 2004, and were one of the first same-sex couples to do so in the country. Though the couple divorced in 2009, they’ve remained friends and raised daughter Annie together.

videos.questionasked: What does this moment in history mean for the LGBT community?
videos.video_quotes: "Once we have same-sex federal marriage we will finally be on an equal playing field."
videos.sharelanguage: "Once we have same-sex federal marriage we will finally be on an equal playing field." @malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.videodescription: Mala says this moment will touch many Americans. She says that we currently have a “piece wise” system of gay marriage, where those who do not have the resources to live in a state where same-sex marriage is legal are at disadvantage.

project_head:
OUR COUNTRY IS AT A CROSSROADS. IN APRIL, THE SUPREME COURT WILL HEAR ORAL ARGUMENTS ABOUT WHETHER STATE BANS ON SAME-SEX MARRIAGES ARE CONSTITUTIONAL.

MEN AND WOMEN WITHIN THE GAY COMMUNITY SHARE THEIR STORIES ABOUT WHY THEY WANT FEDERAL MARRIAGE RIGHTS.
